conclusion: Understanding the problem involves a charged ball moving in an electric field and finding the change in electric potential energy.
Identifying forces acting on the ball: electric force and gravity.
Electric field is horizontal; ball starts at point O with velocity v₀ at angle θ opposite to E.
Velocity component opposite to E is v₀ cos θ, and perpendicular component is v₀ sin θ.
Net force must be along the line of motion, which is at angle θ with respect to the horizontal.
Electric force is F_e = qE (horizontal) and gravity is F_g = mg (downward).
Net force is F_net = sqrt(F_e² + F_g²) along the direction of motion.
Net force should be in the direction of the acceleration, which is the same as the motion.
Unit vector in the direction of motion is \(\hat{d} = \cos 	heta \hat{i} + \sin 	heta \hat{j}\).
Electric force vector is \(\vec{F_e} = qE \hat{i}\) and gravity vector is \(\vec{F_g} = -mg \hat{j}\).
Net force vector is \(\vec{F_net} = qE \hat{i} - m g \hat{j}\).
Net force direction is \(\vec{F_net} = F \cos 	heta \hat{i} + F \sin 	heta \hat{j}\).
Comparing components: \(qE = F \cos 	heta\) and \(m g = F \sin 	heta\).
Expression for \(\cot 	heta\): \(qE / m g = \cot 	heta\).
Considering work done by electric force to find change in electric potential energy.
Initial velocity components: horizontal is v₀ cos θ, vertical is v₀ sin θ.
Electric force affects horizontal motion, gravity affects vertical motion.
